g'day good morning my name is Alex I am the head of the
enterprise business unit here in Australia I've been with Amazon for a bit over six years and now me first of
all say thank you for making time to join us both in this session but also at
the summit today's session is going to focus on what we call organizational
capabilities and we're focusing on organizational capabilities because about three years ago we saw a tangible
shift in the market from organizations really increasing their focus and their
need to build new capabilities and establish new ways of working and Amazon
we talked about this concept of creating a future ready business and we see customers increasingly looking to do
this to cater for increasing rates of disruption and as they pursue these new capabilities what we see is they're not
only looking to cater for disruption but ideally put themselves in a position where they can take advantage of
disruption and even be the disruptor so that's going to be the focus of the session today but to start off we feel
it's relevant to look at some of the factors that are increasing the rate of disruption in local and global markets
this graph is from an insight research report that was released last year and
what it does is it looks at the average tenure of an S&P 500 company and it's
kind of a tough time at the moment and you look at this increasing rate of decline so from the early 80s it was
about 36 years was the average tenure right now in 2019 it's 24 years and it's
forecasted to reduce to 12 years by 2027 the alarming factory is 50% of the S&P
500 is due to churn in the next 10 years three factors are contributing to this
increase increasing rate of decline and there are advances in biotech social
media and cloud computing interesting tonight cloud computing plays a major role
the other two and these three factors are fueling an increasingly buoyant
startup community and so never before have we seen the diversity of startups
and the number of startups achieve scale in such a short period of time now the
challenge for traditional businesses working in an environment where we have this increasing number of startups is
these startups don't have legacy they don't have legacy tech they don't have legacy process structures politics
additionally these organizations more often than not have a very customer centric product creation and ideation
process and lastly they have a culture of rapid iteration and innovation and so
the challenge for people working in markets for these startups are arriving in both b2b and b2c markets they are
redefining customer experience they're raising the bar and shifting the playing
field and the challenge is these new customer experiences very quickly become the customer expectation by which you
are judged we really started noticing
this shift about three years ago and the way we noticed this shift was the change
in customer conversations that we were having so historically a lot of our conversations were quite tech orientated
and they focused on cost three years ago we saw this shift and it wasn't
overnight but it was quite rapid this shift in the dialogue that we were having with customers move to what we
call business centric or business value subjects and across a range of industries here in Australia we saw
three consistent themes there were staff productivity how do I get more from my
staff how do I get greater output and when we look at staff productivity it's not just teams such as developers we saw
a range of conversations including call centres field teams in mining logistics
and it was a common theme what we also saw was organisations have a significant
focus on increasing operational resilience and security and lastly this concept of
agility how do you help me cater for the disruption that is either occurring or coming but how do you help me be the
disrupter and so we saw this shift from these traditional cost and tech
conversations into business very discussions and during this time we saw
a small number of customers move significantly faster and this prompted
us to start looking at why why was there a small number of customers that was that we're really moving away from the
mass market and so we started to scratch and what we noticed was capital
allocation was tangibly different now this is this is kind of a management
consulting 101 when you're working with an organization who's struggling to change or implement strategy one of the
first things you do is you look at the strategic priorities and the allocation of capital and so we did tend we noticed
that the organizations that were moving faster had clearly defined and greater allocation of capital to their
transformation and cloud programs but what we saw and what we had pathi sized over was this was a lagging indicator
this was not the root cause as to why they were moving faster and so that
prompted us to do some more scratching and more investigation now we are very
lucky we're very privileged here in Australia we've been operating for nearly seven years we have over a hundred thousand active customers across
a huge range of industries and our professional services organization has done hundreds of engagements and our
partner ecosystem has done thousands of engagements and so we have quite a significant ecosystem and body of work
from which we can start exploring these themes and so as we went through these organisations moving faster what we
found was there was five reoccurring themes five capabilities that were
present in organisations that were achieving more and achieving it faster and they were leadership understanding
the role of leadership are skills as a priority looking at cloud as a as an
enabler to security not a challenge modes of operation have
clearly defined ways that they were going to run applications within their
business including what were the capabilities and controls associated with that and I'm going to come back a little and and provide a little bit more
detail on that and then data and seeing data as a strategic priority not just in technology but within the business and
so when we look at this concept of these themes and these capabilities one of the
things we did was we started to triangulate our observations and so we started looking at the leading companies
that were moving fastest in asia-pacific and then we looked at leading companies globally such as Capital One in America
and what we found through this process of triangulation was that these themes continued to be validated as the call
that drove speed and outcomes full transparency potentially career limiting
these themes and capabilities are agnostic they're not specific to Amazon
and I would suggest that they actually will work with any cloud provider we probably have a preference that we have
a fairly good cloud platform on Amazon but it's agnostic and I and I state that very clearly if we look at modes of
operation for a minute and I just want to unpick this and just define it now because it's really important because
this is an area where we have a lot of customers struggle to define we look at
modes of operation really in two key themes we look at Enterprise ops and we
look at DevOps Enterprise Ops is really focused on your legacy apps your cots
apps you're packaged apps and what we're looking to do with these applications is to drive greater performance and
resilience and cost improvement these apps more often than not run your
business and are critical but they don't differentiate your business they're not creating competitive advantage in the
marketplace these applications what we look at is really two ways to cater for Enterprise Ops first of all managed ops
and managed Sox is really the process of leveraging a third party that provides a
management framework out-of-the-box whether that be Amazon menu services so we have a funk
that we're going to talk through today whether it be s AP and some of their managed services whether it be a systems integrator or partner but the process of
looking at a set of standards in regards to how you can run your applications and
your operations out of the box what this allows you to do is to minimize the
capabilities that you must build in your business the second part of Enterprise Ops is cloud ops and this is the same
concept in regards to these are still the same set of applications but cloud ops looks at building the capability in
your business and so what we see as you build the capabilities in your business there's an increase in requirement in
capabilities that you must establish within your organization Enterprise ops
usually has a change frequency that is measured in months and quarters with a
strong focus on performance resilience and cost the other side of Enterprise ops is what we call DevOps
and now the challenges you ask you know a lot of people or a hundred people what is the definition of DevOps you get a
hundred different views we have a really simple view of DevOps and Amazon you build it you run it and so DevOps is the
mode of operation that really focuses on high value business applications
applications that will provide you tangible competitive advantage in the market applications where you are either
building them from the ground up or you have access to the full code stack and they usually have a fairly rapid change
velocity so we're measuring in hours and days so these are the concepts of modes
of operation now the advantage of being able to define and understand this at
the start is really twofold first of all it allows you to focus on the controls
and the capabilities you're going to build versus those that you're going to leverage what it also does is it helps
with what we call workload placement and so we work with a lot of organizations and we see a consistent question which
is how do I run my applications how do I determine the operating model for all
the variety of applications I have and when you establish your modes of operations at the start it provides you
with a clear guide I'll give you an example and this is one from we did at the end of last year once we
define the modes of operations that are going to establish and you can do two modes three modes there's no hard and
fast rule but you define it at the start as they went through their application landscape it allowed them to ask a
series of really simple questions was it an application that ran the business or was an application that
provided competitive advantage did it differentiate them in the market was it a cots or a packaged application or was
an application that they were building what was the change frequency within that workload or that application and
what were the capabilities that they had internally to run the application in different modes of operation and through
four or five questions what we found is really quickly with a high level of accuracy we could determine across their
application landscape where applications should be migrated to so let's unpick
the the model just a little bit more
organizations that are moving faster and achieving greater outcomes have three
key themes that we see from leadership first of all there's an understanding of
the difference between management that is really focused on establishing and maintaining the status quo versus
leadership which is focused on driving change and in organizations that are moving fast to what we see is there's
usually one or a small group of executives that assumed the role of
leadership and it's quite defining across all our all our organizations that we work with the second thing we
see from this from this leadership function is great clarity of purpose
they have a great understanding and communication of why that business must change and what that allows them to do
is to take the business on the journey and the business needs to go on the journey and it needs to be from the

we did with National Australia Bank before they launched their transformation program we spent a number
of quarters with their board their leadership team both here in Australia and you now head office in

understanding why and understanding transformation and really validating the need for them to move and as the bank

need to move and why they needed to move
and once you understand the need to move what we see then is organizations that
focus on skills be able to move faster skills we look out from our observations
in regards to these organizations that are moving comes in three three areas first of all the skills element itself
and there's two basic elements here one is training your people and thinking about training your people at a
multi-dimensional level so what is the knowledge or awareness that our business
unit MD needs to have this as a business unit GM versus your technical leaders and your hardcore developers and coders
and thinking about doing a training program that it provides awareness throughout the organization what these
companies also do is they think very deliberately around attracting Tapp top
talent top talent both locally and globally and so they really look at an external communications program to start
talking about what a great place it is to work in that organization but the
challenge is training people and hiring people is not a short-term fix it's more
of a medium to in play and it's really important when you're driving change and transformation that you move into action
as quickly as possible and so organizations moving fastest consistently will leverage external
organizations whether that be AWS whether it be our partners they're bringing in subject matter experts
people that are highly skilled with experience to enable them to move into action really quickly what that allows
is first of all for them to move it accelerates the learning process so their teams are learning in the

them to ensure that they're doing it right and they're doing it safe and secure and then what happens is

what happens is barriers are broken down and individuals and teams reimagine the
out of the possible and when you see the art of the possible occuring you get this groundswell of appetite to do more

I think most of you in this room will know NAB in fact probably about 20% of

now occur on digital channels so our customers are expecting us to act like
born in the cloud providers they're expecting us to provide the same

after your money now traditionally in such a complex environment the way we
handle governance and security was to develop a culture of no all right I want
to do something new well the default position is no until you've jumped through a hundred hoops to
prove why what you're doing is safe and secure for our customers that doesn't
work in the digital world we need a completely different solution if we are
going to be fast and agile if we're going to be relevant and certainly we
cannot afford to have our systems down at any time now a few years ago it
didn't matter if our services were down from midnight to 6:00 a.m. for maintenance now it does because there's
a lot of people using it so how do we address that security is really
important to us it's probably our well it's not even probably it is the most
important thing about running our business we are a bank so what we needed to do is to create a

that culture of the default answer being no the default question now is does a
comply with caste now because we've moved our infrastructure to the cloud we
now have infrastructure as code we could also have compliance as code once you
have that so we've been able to take most of the controls within cask and
automate them and that's what it looks like we call it invisible compliance why
because our developers don't need to actually run through every one of the
compliance checks that we do in a manual way anymore when they fire up a new instance you can

and have a look at what that developers doing without the developer having to do anything and work out whether they're

that code it'll look for things like whether or not we've tagged the

operational controls whether it's defined to be patched and backed up at a cert
time.whether there's business continuity in place is it running over multiple availability zones and multiple clouds
all of that is checked and ticked off without the developer having to look at
it that sort of really taken us into a new area and allowed us to do or to
implement our cloud workloads in a really agile way but also safely we also
apply it at different levels so if you're experimenting with something we don't force particular controls on you
they gradually tear up so for instance yes if you're in creating a environment
to do an experiment still has to be tagged we still have to know what it's for we sell have to know that it's
actually not they're doing some bad thing that it's actually part of a
formal experiment but we don't do things like ensure that you're running in multiple availability zones for instance
that's not required for an experiment and as we go through the different stages of development those controls
gradually ratchet up so by the time you're going into production 100% of the
controls are checked and in place but it's part of the blueprint we also
wanted to look at the modes of operation and NAB has taken a very similar

because we didn't write it we don't hold the source code so the whole you build it you run it doesn't apply and it's

that allows us to to put those packaged
acts in an environment and run them in a tight governance model but to do it at
Pace and the reason we can do it at Pace is because AMS is triggered via ap is
everything that you want to do all of the operations that you typically want to do in a workload is done via an API
so if you want to do a change there's no form to fill in there's no change board
there's no approvals that need to go through well there are but they are all automated so as a owner is a service

call would go across to Amazon most of the changes they have what's called the constraint change which means they're
automated that change would be run it'll be automatically tested if the test
fails an incident will be automatically opened if an incident automatically opened it will come back into our ITSM

doing on our behalf and most of what they're doing on our behalf is automated anyway so it gives us this ability to
run your traditional I wouldn't say ITIL
but your traditional waterfall type management techniques but in a really
fast and sophisticated way last month we ran 5,000 changes across 120
applications that we have running in AMS 5,000 changes is a lot in one month over
a hundred apps right normally I was surprised I was like wow 5,000 changes
how can that be these are packaged apps we're not going in and doing major changes on them why and when I dug into it it turned out
that those changes were always happening we just weren't recording them they were
things like tiny tweaks on this or a movie or a change in parameter on this that
never used to be recorded people would just go in and do them because that was deemed as operations all part of an
